title: 108_hr2129
content: The Act may be cited as the "Taunton, Massachusetts Special Resources Study Act". The city of Taunton, Massachusetts is home to 9 historic districts with over 600 properties on the National Register of Historic Places. These districts include buildings of historical, cultural, and architectural significance. Taunton Green was where the Sons of Liberty raised the Liberty and Union Flag in 1774, sparking the American Revolution. Robert Treat Paine, a Taunton citizen, was a signer of the Declaration of Independence. Taunton was also a prominent community during the Industrial Revolution. The city of Taunton, Massachusetts has a rich history with 9 historic districts and over 600 properties on the National Register of Historic Places. Taunton Green was significant during the American Revolution, and the city has preserved artifacts dating back to its founding in 1638. Taunton continues to attract immigrants, contributing to Southeastern Massachusetts' unique ethnic character. SEC. 3. STUDY. The Secretary, in consultation with relevant organizations, will conduct a special resources study on designating historic buildings and areas in Taunton, Massachusetts as a unit of the National Park System. The study will assess management feasibility, cultural significance, and historical value of the areas in Taunton. The Secretary will conduct a special resources study on designating historic buildings and areas in Taunton, Massachusetts as a unit of the National Park System. The study will assess management feasibility, cultural significance, and historical value of the areas in Taunton. The designated areas should provide valuable parts of the national story, opportunities for conservation, recreational and educational activities, and can be managed in partnership with various entities to support local economic activity. The Secretary will submit a report to Congress on the findings of the study within 3 years of funding availability. Private landowner concerns regarding designating certain structures as part of the National Park System will be considered. Appropriations are authorized for the implementation of this Act.
